WRITING.TEXT:
The show knows it's ridiculous. It leans into it. That Giamatti "seed" monologue is a perfect example, and what I love about the show.
I really doubt anyone has ever talked like that.
This oft-cited critique has always irked me. I couldn't care less about verisimilitude as a hard-and-fast rule, especially with regard to style of dialogue. This is fiction, not a documentary. No one talks like David-Milch-in-*Deadwood*- or Sorkin- or Amy Sherman-Palladino-written dialogue. edit: typo, clarity

One of the best written shows on TV today.
It really is. It's a different kind of writing than I think normally gets extolled on TV -- hyper-naturalistic, minimalist; *The Americans*-style -- but damn if there isn't a show written as fun, or purely-entertaining as *Billions*.

Shows purported to be making "the leap" are opinions perhaps thrown around a bit liberally these days, but *Billions* Season 2 definitely qualifies IMO. I liked *Billions* last season; I'm loving it now.

Fun fact: Lorenzo Brown [led the D-League in PER this year](http://go.redirectingat.com/?id=66960X1516590 site=Sbnation.com xs=1 isjs=1 url=http%3A%2F%2Fbasketball.realgm.com%2Fdleague%2Fstats%2F2017%2FAdvanced_Stats%2FQualified%2Fpoints%2FAll%2Fdesc%2F1%2FRegular_Season xguid=57651e360a326fbc2c6b46e7eaf88ccc xuuid=b14fd89a3b4ab7bd5a21a5c5632ca2e2 xsessid=6acb52321c2fdc8a9ec94face2d4df95 xcreo=0 xed=0 sref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.detroitbadboys.com%2F2017%2F4%2F9%2F15240232%2Fpistons-at-grizzlies-final-score-boban-and-three-point-shooting-carries-pistons-win-103-90%23423297733 pref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sbnation.com%2Fusers%2Fsje%3F_ga%3D1.149408496.754896372.1491409864 xtz=240)
He was a 19-year-old 18th pick. He was always expected to play the majority of the season in the D-League, and that's what he did -- in which he had a negative Box Plus-Minus btw.

I'd say he's more of a combo PF/C than PF, let alone combo forward, but yeah, he's slow as molasses and not very explosive at all. His defense reflects such; it's really bad and likely will forever be a challenge/issue for him.

Remaining an NFL fan these days isn't as easy as it used to be. Goodell, concussions, Toradol and team doctors, handling of off-field issues...The list goes on, and on...

Levy initially posted an Instagram story Wednesday, using a picture where he is in a full-length knee brace and on crutches and captioning it "'your knee is fine,' they said."
"Still had the same issues emerge in March as from December/January," Levy said in an email to ESPN. "Turns out there was a little more damage than I was being told and there's no way I should've been back on the field last year."
In March, he said "hell no, I wasn't even close" to being fully healthy when he returned to the field. ([ESPN](http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/19093011/former-lions-lb-deandre-levy-another-knee-surgery-following-torn-meniscus))
So, yes. Upstanding NFL team doctors strike again.

**It underlines the value of HBOs linear-centric model.**
Given Netflixs track record for giving talent plenty of creative freedom, as well as for nurturing positive publicity for its best shows, theres little doubt BLL wouldve emerged a success had it ended up on streaming. But whats less clear is whether or not BLL would have delivered the same emotional and cultural wallop had all the episodes dropped at once, sandwiched between some new Marvel show and another season of Grace and Frankie. Theres a case to be made that having this story play out over the course of two months allowed viewers the time to savor and appreciate each installment, even as positive word-of-mouth among early adopters helped the shows overall audience expand.
Nielsen numbers certainly suggest BLL built momentum during its run. The shows February 19 premiere brought in a solid 1.1 million same-day viewers; Sundays finale scored just under 2 million. This doesnt mean the series doubled its overall audience from start to finish, but the fact that its linear audience grew almost every week it aired indicates buzz about BLL broke through and helped recruit new fans. This happens with Netflix shows, to a degree: Stranger Things stans on social media wouldnt shut up about the show last summer, a fact with no doubt contributed to the impression (not corroborated by data, since Netflix releases none) that the show was a smash. But a linear run on an old-school network such as HBO amplifies and concentrates that buzz in a way the Netflix model doesnt allow.
Entertainment-centric websites such as Vulture spent the week leading up to Sundays finale speculating about how the show would end and testifying to its virtues. Social media similarly lit up during and immediately after the finale, publicizing the now-complete limited series to millions of potential new viewers (and possible new HBO subscribers). Top Netflix and Amazon shows also get plenty of publicity and hype, but the attention comes in shorter bursts and fades more quickly. By sticking to a linear model, HBO maximizes the attention it gets for its best series. Plus, thanks to the companion digital platforms such as HBO Go and HBO Now, the network can still satisfy the Netflix generation by letting subscribers who want to the opportunity to binge all seven episodes. Bottom line: The networks model gives it the best of both worlds. You can bet the next time a talent agency is shopping a star-studded project to various outlets, HBO will cite BLL as a reason why said project should end up on cable and not streaming.
I think that's a great point. I'm glad it wasn't dumped all at once on Netflix. The communal popularity of this show was one of its more exciting aspects to me; fewer and fewer shows are experiencing that specific week-to-week, consistent mass engagement these days. edit: clarity

But then it illustrates it with **Game of Thrones, which generally does a great job of making each episode compelling** even when there's not much to distinguish where one episode ends and another begins
Downvote away, Reddit, but I gotta disagree big-time here. The middle of GOT seasons tend to get *very* slow for me. They become series of checkings-in, or vignettes of various characters around the larger universe without any real episodic payoff or overarching theme, because those are meant to come towards the end of the season. Like the author of this article is saying, I don't think you need to forgo the episode as a unit (in lieu of a bunch of disparate scenes), for the season as a whole. You can have both.
